educational_objective: Diagnose an infected diabetic foot ulcer.
question_text: A 62-year-old woman with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presents with foul-smelling drainage from a chronic ulceration on her foot. She reports no pain at the site.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is an infected diabetic foot ulcer (Option A). Patients with diabetes mellitus are prone to the development of foot ulcers following minor trauma owing to neuropathy, peripheral vascular disease, and impaired wound healing. Chronic ulcers are particularly prone to infection, especially in patients with poor glycemic control, untreated vasculopathy, and neuropathy. Infection of a chronic ulcer is diagnosed when purulence or two or more inflammatory signs (erythema, warmth, induration, pain, or tenderness) are present. Underlying osteomyelitis is a common complication of infected ulcers.
